Well, its not really surprising that Overwatch 2 launched on steam to a reception of "Mostly Negative," I do hope that this improves in the future because I love this game, but Blizzard needs to do a better job at getting their customers trust back.

This is an interesting decision to launch this game on steam, I think the first of it's kind in terms of Blizz games. Be aware that when you are looking at things like Steam Charts this likely does not include players from BNET, Xbox, PlayStation, or Nintendo Switch.

Since there are already a lot of reviews discussing what they dislike about the game (it DOES have flaws, what games today don't, but I will let others explain them, I wanna give you a glimpse at the other side), I want to discuss what I like about this game and why I've been playing, with over 1,400 hours, since early 2019.

[h1] PVP [/h1] 

While PVP was not necessarily the major selling point of Overwatch 2 it maintains a strong presence if you enjoy player vs player type games. Overwatch is still a Hero shooter, so If you enjoy things like TF2, Paladins and to an extent things like Apex: Legends or Valorant, you will likely enjoy OW2. 

My favorite thing about the Heroes that are available to play is that there is literally a Hero for almost any play style you could think of. If you like playing Snipers, we got Widow and Ana, like builders? Sym and Torb, like changing things up and meleeing in an fps? we got Reinhardt and Brigitte, and many many more heroes, it is probably one of the most versatile fps because you can still have an impact on heroes that are less mechanically demanding almost at the same level of heroes that are incredibly mechanically demanding.

Ever since Overwatch 2 launched PVP has consistently been getting new content to play, we get a new hero about every 4 months, there's typically new events and limited modes that are available to play, New balance patches every 4 weeks so stuff is always changing it's not stagnant like Overwatch 1 was.

There are many modes to play if one thing or another isn't your cup of tea. For instance we have Role lock if you want more structured teams, open queue if you wanna remove those restrictions, mystery heroes if you don't know what to play, deathmatch if you like more of a FFA type game. Also active ranked modes to test your skills and Arcade modes if you want to play with different modifiers that adjust the game. There is also a HUGE custom game community with a bunch of community created gamemodes using the Workshop system.

This is just to explain that if there is not something you want to do there are a bunch of alternatives for almost every player type too. The reason I've been playing so long is because the gameplay loop is just fun and if I get bored of one thing I can do something else. There's not greater feeling than using an ultimate, or making an insane play by using your wits/abilities.

[h1] PVE [/h1]

The big launch recently is the PVE. Right now we have about 4 missions. 3 Story missions with about ~30mins in length each, fully rendered pre and post cinematics, dialogue between multiple characters. unique enemy types, and 1 sort of repayable mission that will have unique modifiers throughout the month. As well as a massive lore dump.

Personally I think Overwatch 2's PVE is A LOT better than the archive missions from the past, but I think there is still a lot to improve on. There are multiple difficulties if you want to play a more relaxed version or a more difficult version. It's like a mini-campaign and honestly I'm okay with that, I like it. We need more, I hope we get more, I think the team did a really good job at making each of these missions more unique than the last. I played each of these on expert and they were fairly difficult to do, so there is a challenge. It didn't feel like 30 minutes of gameplay it feels a lot longer, I think the pacing is great.

My only regret is that we did not get more released at this time.

You can really see that despite the execs decisions, there was a lot of heart and soul put into creating this and I think we should recognize what the devs, voice actors, sound designers, artists, etc have done.

I have hopium that the pve will continue to improve, and it's not like they can't introduce more stuff in the future. I hope they just don't abandon it given the community perception currently. This universe has some of the best characters, interactions, lore/storytelling I have seen in almost any multiplayer game, it would be a shame to not continue there stories and see where the world of Overwatch is heading. It always makes me beg and wish that we had a TV show or Movie because I think it would be awesome.

If you are a fan of OW I can recommend spending money for the PVE. If you are iffy I would wait till we get some more story missions before spending your money. If you just wanna know what happens go to Youtube. 

[h1] Misc: [/h1]

Just gonna fit the other stuff I love about Overwatch here:

[list]
    [*]The lore in this game is phenominal, you can really get connected to the characters that you play. There are so many stories, comics, cinematics and books. Almost every character has a solidified backstory that connect them to the greater world. 
    [*]The game is super diverse, there are characters from many backgrounds, ethnicities and even LGBTQ representation.
    [*]Blizzard Polish is still here and it is phenomenal as always. The maps, the designs, the skins, the lack of significant bugs.
    [*]Despite what some say, the devs do a good job at communicating with the playerbase since OW2 started and we get fairly consistent blog updates.
    [*]I'm not a F2P player but if you are there is still a lot of things you can unlock as a new players. Most of the hero roster is free and the new heroes are made free after the season ends. They always have a new event active with new skins, there is a free tier in the battle pass and of course twitch drops. YOU DON'T NEEDS SKINS to be good at the game and the new player experience is really good.
[/list]

+578 hours from Battle.net

[h1]PVP[/h1]
Overwatch's PVP gameplay loop is pretty solid. A relatively fun mode, albeit a mostly toxic community makes it a bit dicey at times. Would recommend against playing the competitive mode for that point alone.

[h1]PVE[/h1]
Overwatch's PVE gameplay loop is currently quite stale. Fun for a singular playthrough, but to be candid, their older OW1 "Archives" event had better and more unique PVE scenarios, and therefore more replayability. There's not much variance in what you're tasked to do and the enemies you fight. 

Widespread PVE is still a newer part of the game, so it's very likely this'll change, but releasing a very stale free mission and putting the remaining at-launch ones behind a $15-25 paywall does not instill trust.

[h1]Microtransactions[/h1]
Speaking of, the current F2P + microtransaction setup for OW2 is awful. It attempts to coax you into cracking open your wallet at essentially every juncture. In OW1, this was just cosmetics, cosmetics you could get for free if you played enough. However now, there are some things you absolutely have to pay for, including playable content. 

This has the possibility of being rational, given that the game is now free, but the sheer lack of new content (both free and paid) makes this impossible to defend. OW1's monetization was great for the consumer and still offered Blizzard substantial money. OW2's painful monetization screws over the consumer and makes Blizzard even more money.

[h1]Balancing[/h1]
As for overall balance, OW1 and OW2 have some notable differences. The first is a change from 6v6 to 5v5. Might be a controversial take, but this has been a fresh improvement for the game. Makes the gameplay faster, makes it less about shooting and wearing down shields. However, it has forced tanks to become generalist vs a main and an off tank. Blizzard hasn't balanced this yet, and some tanks absolutely suck whereas some absolutely shred. The lack of two tanks does make the tank role a bit more stale at times too.

The second and final main change is their hero balancing. They've never been great at it, even in OW1, but for OW2 they've had an obsession with converting more specialized heroes into generalists. For some heroes this has been great, for others, it has removed fun and unique parts of their kits. They've removed stuns and Mei's freeze, but still have pencil-thin one-shot snipers. Makes the gameplay a lot more stale and repetitive, makes freshness and fun depend on developer patches rather than player choice.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
Given all of this, the rebranding from OW1 to OW2 was essentially just a marketing gimmick and excuse to charge for more macrotransactions. They flopped on delivering robust PVE, and haven't really added anything substantially new in quite a while. It's clear the devs still care, as the training range and new additions have been made with notable effort, but in terms of newness and freshness, nothing to warrant a sequel just yet.

停更几年，画了N年大饼的守望先锋2就是这玩意？改动还没个版本更新大，这些年员工都在忙什么？办公室性骚扰？看看当年守望2预告CG动画里老玩家的弹幕，现今看来只有2个字：心寒。逼肝骗氪就不说了，反正暴雪现在也就只会这个，我的战役模式呢？信誓旦旦的PVE一拖再拖，张口就是为了玩家更好的体验这些晦涩难懂的词。

再聊私事：
账号承载着老玩家的青春回忆，见证了和朋友一起欢笑犯糗的时光。你说没就没，这就是您说的为了玩家？向钱看嘛，不寒掺，哪怕您站直了脊梁骨，说几句真话，我对您的鄙夷也能少那么几分，来洗的暴白也会多一点。中国玩家不重要，但中国玩家的真金白银很重要。


新玩家的避坑理由
在这里，你能感受到如同上班一样的游玩快感
在这里，你会发现皮肤出的比版本更新更加勤快
在这里，你可以体会到原汁原味的正宗暴雪式傲慢
在这里，你能够看到无数新的承诺簇拥出的艰难决定
在这里，你将游玩一个拒绝中国市场和中国玩家的高贵洋产，玩之前，先低头再折腰。

结语：

2016的那个暑假，我上初中没钱买OW，可我非常幸运的有一个好朋友，愿意邀请我去他家玩，我们两个，在他不大的卧室里，风扇嗡嗡，你一条命我一条命玩到我不得不回家。
之后，每到假期，我最期待的就是可以去他家玩一两个小时的OW。
后来，好像是第二年的冬天，守望第一次降价到了98元，没有购买手段的我想到了一个“绝佳”的购买游戏方法，我拿着一点一点存的三百多块零花钱，去手办店买了一个我当时最喜欢的雷姆小手办，想着手办店老板看我买了东西肯定愿意帮我个小忙买个游戏的，于是我总算有了自己的OW账号。
后来，升学，搬家，家里发生了很多不顺心的事情，和好朋友打几把OW依然可以给我带来快乐
因为搬家，OW成了我和初中朋友聊天娱乐的唯一途径
后来国服没了，归来出了，朋友们也散了
我想，OW吸引我的，可能早在不知不觉间从有趣的玩法变成了那几个朋友的欢声笑语
游戏在改变，我也在成长
以此纪念那段无忧无虑的时光
